title: How to Find Photographic Inspiration

steps.headline: Try taking a look at your camera manual.
steps.description: Research something about it that you don't quite get. Get out there and practice doing it.

steps.headline: Read a newspaper.
steps.description: Catch up on current events and see if there is anything that sparks your interest.

steps.headline: Go to a flea market.
steps.description: There is liable to be lots of things there that you don't normally see.

steps.headline: Use your favorite search engine and surf for ideas.
steps.description: Google Image is one place you can look for lots of ideas.

steps.headline: Change your perspective.
steps.description: If you are normally up on your feet shooting 'convenient' things, try crawling around on the ground.

steps.headline: Look around the Internet and find some photo blogs.
steps.description: There are a lot out there. Follow, friend, or whatever you can do to keep up with them.

steps.headline: Make friends with other photographers.
steps.description: Find others with common interests. Have a meet-up with them.

steps.headline: Take a class.
steps.description: Taking a photography class will help you find other photographers and broaden your skill set.

steps.headline: Mess around with the settings of your camera.
steps.description: Most people find a single setting and stick with it. Try something different.

steps.headline: Look through your old photos.
steps.description: See if you can find something you could do better or different.

text: Try taking a look at your camera manual. Research something about it that you don't quite get. Get out there and practice doing it. Read a newspaper. Catch up on current events and see if there is anything that sparks your interest. Go to a flea market. There is liable to be lots of things there that you don't normally see. Use your favorite search engine and surf for ideas. Google Image is one place you can look for lots of ideas. Change your perspective. If you are normally up on your feet shooting 'convenient' things, try crawling around on the ground. Look around the Internet and find some photo blogs. There are a lot out there. Follow, friend, or whatever you can do to keep up with them. Make friends with other photographers. Find others with common interests. Have a meet-up with them. Take a class. Taking a photography class will help you find other photographers and broaden your skill set. Mess around with the settings of your camera. Most people find a single setting and stick with it. Try something different. Look through your old photos. See if you can find something you could do better or different.
